summary: Dr. John Oni Akerele, a licensed medical practitioner, was convicted of manslaughter and a related charge of reckless or negligent conduct under sections 325 and 345(1)(f) of the Criminal Code for administering an overdose of the drug Sobita (sodium-bismuth-tartrate) to a patient, Kalu Ibe, who died from resulting toxaemia and oral sepsis. The West African Court of Appeal dismissed his appeal, affirming that the evidence— including the deaths of nine other children similarly treated—was properly admitted to prove the dose was an overdose and not due to individual idiosyncrasy. The court rejected a technical challenge to the coroner's committal, finding no substantial miscarriage of justice. It also held that Nigerian law on criminal negligence does not differ materially from English law, requiring a high degree of negligence amounting to a crime against the state. The trial judge's findings of fact—that the death resulted from an overdose and that the doctor's conduct was criminally negligent—were upheld as supported by ample evidence.
verdict: Conviction for manslaughter and reckless conduct upheld; appeal dismissed.
citations: West African Court of Appeal Ordinance, 1933 (No. 47 of 1933)
rationaleHighlights: Admission of evidence regarding deaths of other patients was proper to disprove idiosyncratic reaction and establish overdose
Coroner's failure to formally find guilt did not vitiate committal as it was a technical defect without substantial injustice
Standard for criminal negligence in Nigeria aligns with English law: must show disregard for life rising to a crime against the state
Section 303 of the Criminal Code imputes causation but does not lower threshold for criminal liability
Conviction upheld due to overwhelming evidence of gross negligence in administering dangerous drug
